comment_text: There is also a "cold process - hot process" method, where you make solid soap using the cold process, and then put it in the oven to speed up the reaction. When making hot process soap, don’t allow the liquid in the container to go beyond the half-way point: when the hot lye water and the hot oils meet in a hot slow cooker, the reaction can result in expansion and a boil-over. If you see that this is about to happen, IF you can move the slow cooker to the floor safely before the contents actually make their way out, that’ll make clean-up easier; otherwise, LEAVE THE SLOW COOKER ON THE SURFACE AND ALLOW THE BOIL OVER TO HAPPEN. Clean up is going to be a nightmare, but it’s far better to allow the contents to boil over and not get your hands burned. The hot soap with its corrosiveness will solidify on your hands and do a lot of damage.
Don’t use wood, bamboo, paper, aluminium to mix soap; be cautious of thin plastics.
Do not use ingredients that are known to be irritating when making soap. Like I said in my comment on your solid cold process soap video, *you know this isn’t smart, but you’re not doing what’s smart. You have a responsibility to practice what’s wise for the folks that don’t have the common sense you and I do. Practice what’s prudent...not what’s possible. Look out for the folks that don’t have common sense or respect the danger in making soap. PPE should always be used when making soap: closed-toe shoes, pants, long sleeves, gloves with the sleeves tucked into the gloves, and goggles. Oh, and hair pulled back (I should edit my comment in your other video to mention pulling back long hair). Keep pets, children, and idiots away from you while using lye and hot liquids and heating apparatuses.
This is coming from someone who has studied soap making for ten years and has been making soap for six years. I also have a scar from a chemical burn because of soap making — I wasn’t wearing appropriate PPE because I got too comfortable and too confident in my abilities.

In my experience with solid NaOH, it eventually caused some cracking of the skin on my fingers, which was not pleasant. I was lucky it did not get into my eyes, as we did not have goggles back in the day.

Just curious what kind of slow cooker you are using.  Most Slow cookers (aka Crockpot) have a Low and High Setting, the difference being not so much the temperature that it reaches, as much as it is the time that it takes to get to that temperature.  In other words ... They will both reach (say) 90C, but the low setting may take 6 hours to get to that temp, whereas the High setting would reach that temp in 2 hours.  Just curious if the one that you are using is that way, or does yours have a variable temperature High vs. Low?

I'm confused. Why would borax drop the pH? Borax usually refers to Sodium borate, a salt of a weak acid and thus it contains the conjugate BASE of boric acid, the borate ion!  Salts of weak acids are BASES in solution. Boric ACID would have dropped the pH (and made potassium borate from any remaining base) wouldn't borax RAISE the pH?  I've actually used borax to teach about indicators and its a base and a clear on its own.  It is often added to soaps to make laundry soap which is harsher then hand/face/body or even dish soap (=good for glassware?).  There seems to be online discussions on soap making were people use borax and boric acid interchangeably, which seems bad.

As a soapmaker i would say your demonstration should be named as how not to make liquid soap.. even cold processed, the potassium hydroxide based soap would complete saponification within a short period of time, except with olive oil which known to take hours to reach the trace. If you had used a soap calc, and super fatted it about 3%, you don't have to worry about lowering the pH value either. Borax is a totally irrelevant ingredient, and soapmakers would avoid it even as a thikener alone. There is no need to add boiling water to dilute either. Use distilled water and leave it to sit overnight.

Anyone who wish to make Liquid Soap like the Store.... Try this one....
Water (D.I.) 100.0% Carrier
Sodium Lauryl Sulfate 25.0% Surfactant
Cocamidopropyl Betaine 5.0% Co-Surfactant
Cocamide DEA 3.0% Co-Surfactant
Sodium Chloride (Adjust Viscosity)

NOTE: Add Preservative, Fragrance, Color and mix well.
--- Appearance Clear, homogeneous liquid

Why don't you just call the potassium hydroxide Lye? In soap making that's what it's called, that's all it really is. Besides, if ya'll want to get down to the real situation and not buy it. Burn wood, take some straw or other matter to strain the ashes, then run rain water through the ashes. Catch the lye water in a bucket or container below. Tada! Lye for soap. You can also use leaf lard, the fat prior to being made into lard. You just have to process it down into actual lard. (Oil)

Interestingly, having soap lather makes it less efficient. The bubbles require extra surfactant to be exist, removing it from the solution where they could be stabilizing the oil droplets. But I think the effect is very small, insignificant. Lather is something much more related to our perception of cleanliness and value for money (more lather -> more concentrated soap) than how well it can clean.

tbh, when you said "i want to support an artist" i expected you to say you'd commission something.

i feel like "some free advertising" is another way to say "paid with exposure", which is generally considered poor practise, and artists usually avoid that unless they're desperate.

basically: while it's obvious you do have an engaged audience, what with the patreon and everything, that is often not enough to guarantee to someone else that they'd get increased traffic on their bandcamp or soundcloud, which increases the likelihood of you simply using something someone's finished already and submits just to see if you take it, because they can't risk the time taken to do anything new on such a speculative return.

if you commission an artist, you can give them the guarantee of compensation for their time, and they can work on something much more tailored to your needs.

you're also much more likely to find someone who can properly advise you on how to get what you're wanting, if you're not sure on the musical specifics. people who are good at that generally don't work for free, and wouldn't submit something they'd made for a different client's use case.

naturally it's more of a plunge to take, but since you don't want to just use royalty free music, it's clear you want something a bit more special, and commissioning is absolutely The way to get that.

lots of artists have portfolios to be checked out, so you can get a sense of if they make the kind of thing you want, before you commit to anything. i honestly highly recommend reaching out that way rather than asking for people to make submissions to you.

this website is much more focused on visual design and why people shouldn't work for "design mills", so don't think i'm saying all of a what the site says applies to you or anything! but it goes into the benefits of picking someone and working with them rather than holding a contest, and a contest is kind of what you're doing. http://www.nospec.com i know you're just one guy and not the head of PR for a huge corporation, of course, but these kinds of patterns and power dynamics exist in lots of levels of society, and are important to at least be aware of, i think.

i apologise that my comment ran so long, though this is something i'm fairly passionate about as a lot of my friends are artists of many kinds by trade, and almost everyone who seems to want to work with them falls into parts of this pattern, and they find it very frustrating.
